item.title: Dragon Ball: 8 Best Games For Exploration, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot is a great game for exploration, providing an immersive open world experience.
  • Dragon Ball FighterZ features a new story to explore with unique characters, despite being primarily a fighting game.
  • Dragon Ball Fusions has a huge open world to adventure in, focusing on fusions and answering fans' questions.

Dragon Ball is a franchise that first attracted a fan-base through its incredible anime series that saw the birth of popular characters such as Goku and Vegeta. While many viewers loved the adventures and plot of Dragon Ball and its many spin-off series that followed after it, those who truly enjoy the franchise and also love games have likely also played the various Dragon Ball titles that have been released over the years.

Commonly, these games are fighting titles, with players either taking on other players or the AI in epic battles with their favorite characters. However, there have also been a few Dragon Ball games that have allowed players to lose themselves within the story of Dragon Ball via open-worlds or RPG mechanics. These games are brilliant for those looking to explore the world o f Dragon Ball, though exploration can also be done through unique stories . Although they might not all allow the player to entirely freely roam around the world of Dragon Ball , these are by far the best Dragon Ball games for exploration .

8 Dragon Ball Xenoverse 2

Explore The Hub World Of Conton City

Dragon Ball Xenoverse 2
8 /10
10.0 /10
Released
October 25, 2016

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T For Teen due to Cartoon Violence, Mild Blood, Mild Language, Mild Suggestive Themes
Developer(s)
Dimps
Platform(s)
Nintendo Switch, PC, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Stadia, Xbox One, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S
Powered by

Dragon Ball Xenoverse 2 is a long-standing fighting game that pulled some players in through its character customization and decent – although limited – roster of characters. While this game may not have a large world for the player to walk around in, instead focusing on its combat, that doesn't mean it isn't a great Dragon Ball game for exploration.

With Dragon Ball Xenoverse 2 receiving so many DLCs since its original release back in 2016, the hub world of Conton City has only grown over the years. Besides this hub world, the various battlegrounds for these epic fights are also present across the Dragon Ball world, and this allows players to explore different arcs of the franchise, too. There is also nothing better than how this game can be explored alongside friends.

7 Dragon Ball Z: Sagas

Battle Across Maps Of The Dragon Ball Z Story

Dragon Ball Z: Sagas
7.0 /10
Released
March 22, 2005

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

ESRB
Teen
Developer(s)
Avalanche Software
Platform(s)
Xbox (Original), PlayStation 2, Nintendo GameCube
Powered by

Gamers who are looking for exploration in the Dragon Ball world that they can enjoy with a friend should look no further than the only Dragon Ball game to be released across the 6th generation of consoles, and that is Dragon Ball Z: Sagas . As an action-adventure title, it's important for players to feel as if there is some sort of element of exploration when being a part of the Dragon Ball franchise.

While Dragon Ball Z: Sagas may not have an entirely open world for the player to navigate freely, as they take on various missions within the story of this action-adventure to complete the various beat 'em up moments, the player will visit familiar locations across the 19 missions that are part of several sagas from the anime.

6 Dragon Ball FighterZ

A Whole New Story To Explore

Dragon Ball FighterZ
8.8 /10
Released
January 26, 2018

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T for Teen: Cartoon Violence, Mild Language, Mild Suggestive Themes
Developer(s)
Arc System Works
Platform(s)
PS4, Xbox One, Switch, PC, PS5, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S
Powered by

Dragon Ball FighterZ is possibly one of the best Dragon Ball games of all time, though that doesn't mean that it has the greatest exploration of them all. This is due to it being primarily a fighting game that saw the Dragon Ball franchise finally earn itself a place in the competitive scene of the fighting game genre.

That doesn't mean there is nothing at all for the player to explore and discover within this title, as although Dragon Ball FighterZ has a strong multiplayer presence, the story within Dragon Ball FighterZ is an entirely new one that cannot be found within the anime or the manga. It also marks the introduction of a brand-new character called Android 21, whom the player will learn more about through the campaign of this epic fighting title.

5 Dragon Ball Z: Attack Of The Saiyans

A Little Exploration In A Turn-Based RPG

Dragon Ball Z: Attack of the Saiyans
RPG
Systems
Released
November 10, 2009

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

ESRB
e
Developer(s)
Monolith Soft
Platform(s)
Nintendo DS
Powered by

Handheld consoles were once arguably one of the best ways to enjoy Dragon Ball games, especially for those looking to have an adventure and therefore be able to explore this anime world. One promising entry for the Nintendo DS was Dragon Ball Z: Attack of the Saiyans . In this turn-based RPG, the player has access to a small roster of characters from Dragon Ball Z that many will be familiar with.

As the name of the game suggests, Dragon Ball Z: Attack of the Saiyans focused heavily on the Saiyan Saga, which is only a small part of the Dragon Ball Z franchise, though being able to explore made this DS game a truly unique experience for fans.

4 Dragon Ball Fusions

Fuse Characters Within An Open World

Dragon Ball Fusions
RPG
Anime
Adventure
Systems
Released
November 22, 2016

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

ESRB
T For Teen // Cartoon Violence, Mild Language, Mild Suggestive Themes
Platform(s)
Nintendo 3DS
Powered by

Fusions is a mechanic that few Dragon Ball games have focused on as much as Dragon Ball Fusions on the 3DS has. Similar to the likes of Dragon Ball FighterZ , which creates an entirely new story and character for players to discover, Dragon Ball Fusions proves to be another game where players are left to explore a story that hasn't been seen in the anime or the manga.

Besides the obvious features of fusions in Dragon Ball Fusions , this is one of the few games in the Dragon Ball franchise that has a huge open-world for the player to adventure within. Those who are looking for a Dragon Ball title with great exploration are sure to want to check out Dragon Ball Fusions . It also does a lot to treat players to plenty of fan service and answers many of the questions about fusions.

3 Dragon Ball Z: Buu's Fury

A Sense Of Adventure On The Game Boy Advance

3 Images
3 Images
Dragon Ball Z: Buu's Fury
Action
Systems
Released
September 14, 2004

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

ESRB
e
Developer(s)
Webfoot Technologies
Platform(s)
Nintendo Game Boy Advance
Powered by

As expected, Dragon Ball Z: Buu's Fury focuses on the Majin Buu sagas of the Dragon Ball Z franchise. Similar to what players may have seen on TV or in the manga, Dragon Ball Z: Buu's Fury highlights the thrill of adventure that was seen within this arc of the story. Exploration and adventure go hand in hand in this Action RPG title, which is the final game in the Legacy of Goku series of games.

Exploring on a handheld like the Game Boy Advance is arguably one of the best ways to enjoy not only the Dragon Ball series but also when exploring in general. It's also a surprise that such a small device could hold the vast world of Dragon Ball Z , along with the astounding story and combat that countless players came to love.

2 Dragon Ball Z: The Legacy Of Goku 2

One Of The Greatest Handheld Dragon Ball Experiences

6 Images
6 Images
Dragon Ball Z: The Legacy of Goku II
Action
Systems
Released
June 17, 2003

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

ESRB
e
Platform(s)
Nintendo Game Boy Advance
Powered by

As arguably one of the best action RPGs for the Dragon Ball franchise on the Game Boy Advance, Dragon Ball Z: The Legacy of Goku 2 sits happily alongside Buu's Fury as being two unbelievable titles for gamers to consider when looking for the Dragon Ball games with the best exploration .

As discussed in Buu's Fury , these titles are best for those looking to explore games that take heavy inspiration from their source material while also highlighting the epic adventures that could be followed within the franchise. Gamers who are looking for an experience that is less of a grind should be sure to prioritize trying The Legacy of Goku 2 over Buu's Fury , especially if they are ever looking for a classic game full of exploration.

1 Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot

The Best For Exploring The World Of Dragon Ball

Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot
8.6 /10
Released
January 16, 2020

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T for Teen: Mild Language, Suggestive Themes, Violence
Developer(s)
CyberConnect2
Platform(s)
Stadia, PS4, Switch, Xbox One, PC, PS5, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S
Powered by

Out of all the available Dragon Ball games over the years, by far the best for those looking for exploration is Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot . This is a title that many fans of the Dragon Ball Z franchise believe allows them to feel most like they were a part of the Dragon Ball world.

With Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot fully investing in the immersion of this Action RPG title, there is a whole open world for the player to explore while also being the hero of the tale. When players aren't reliving the epic arcs of the Dragon Ball Z story, they can instead find the time to fly around the map, do a spot of fishing, or even eat a tasty treat as they truly explore.

item.title: What Does the Strange Gem Do in PEAK?
item.description:
The Mesa update in PEAK is finally here, and it has brought loads of new content for players to check out. There are new items to collect, new achievements, and even a new biome to explore. But that’s not all, because the update also brings back an old material from earlier versions of the game: the Strange Gem.

PEAK already had plenty of mysterious items, and now with the Strange Gem making a return, there’s one more mystery for players. So, how do you find the Strange Gem in PEAK , and what can you do with it? Let’s take a look.

How to Get the Strange Gem in PEAK

Players can get the Strange Gem by interacting with the statue at the very top of the peak . If you’ve been playing for a bit, you’ll know that the game has different biomes. After clearing each one, you will eventually come across an Ancient Statue . You can use them to cook food, get a Morale Boost, and even revive your dead teammates. If all your teammates are already alive, the statue will hand over some rare loot instead.

When you clear the final biome and make it to the very top, you will reach the statue. This one’s a bit different from other statues in PEAK . It doesn’t hand out mystical items or bring teammates back. Instead, it gives you the Strange Gem.

This statue is located at the back of the mountain , so it’s easy to miss if you don’t know its location. Once you find it, interact with it. You’ll see the gem in its hands, and its bright pink color makes it easy to notice from a distance. You can collect it like any other item.

What to Do with the Strange Gem in PEAK

At the time of writing, the Strange Gem doesn’t really do anything useful . Sure, it looks fancy, but that’s about it. We even tried offering it to the kiln for the new 24 Karat badge that says you need to ‘offer the kiln a worthy sacrifice,’ but no luck.

The Strange Gem won’t heal you, cure any status effects, or give you any powers. Strangely enough, you can throw it like Dynamite, which is kind of funny, but there’s really no other reason to get it.

Having said that, there’s always a chance it might have a purpose in a future update. If that happens, we will be sure to update this guide so you know exactly what to do with it.

5 Images
5 Images

item.title: Resident Evil Survival Unit Showcases Cast in New Video
item.description:
Resident Evil Survival Unit has released a new cinematic trailer that gives fans a look at the world the Resident Evil cast will be defending. Long-time fans of the franchise may enjoy seeing some familiar faces from the Resident Evil franchise team up over the course of the Resident Evil Survival Unit trailer.

Resident Evil Survival Unit was a surprise when it was announced at Anime Expo 2025. While many fans of the long-running survival horror franchise are focused on the game's next original main series entry, Resident Evil Requiem , Resident Evil Survival Unit could end up offering a lot of fun gameplay to tide players over until Resident Evil Requiem 's release date.

Resident Evil Survival Unit Cinematic Trailer Sets the Stage

A new cinematic trailer has given fans a look at the cast of characters from the Resident Evil franchise that will appear in this mobile spin-off game. As it's a cinematic trailer, there's no gameplay, but it nonetheless serves to amp up hype around the title. The trailer showcases the new lead character arriving on the scene alongside Claire Redfield. Players taking control of this character will give commands and directions to those who actually fight, as the title is a strategy horror game.

There's plenty in this trailer that fans will likely be familiar with, including swarms of mindless zombies, plus bigger, more dangerous creatures. As the trailer progresses, fans can spot a ton of familiar faces, including Jill Valentine, Claire Redfield, Leon S. Kennedy, Carlos Oliveira, Marvin Branagh, Mikhail Viktor, and even a brief glimpse of Ada Wong. Characters in the trailer utilize multiple types of weapons, ranging from their standard sidearms to more memorable firepower-heavy varieties, like giving Leon a rocket launcher and Jill her railgun from Resident Evil 3 Remake . A brief tease also indicates that some of the franchise's terrifying boss enemies will return, including a giant crocodile, Mr. X, and Nemesis. The new Mortem antagonist, which was designed by legendary Final Fantasy artist Yoshitaka Amano, also makes an appearance.

Gamers inspired by the sight of these popular characters in Resident Evil Survival Unit can pre-register for the game now, with the title slated to launch sometime in 2025. It seems that, despite being a mobile spin-off, the game has already succeeded in commanding a lot of attention. According to the game's website, the title has already reached its goal of 1 million pre-registrations, which has unlocked a number of freebies that will be distributed when the game launches.

5 Images
5 Images

Systems

item.title: 8 Most Technically Impressive SNES Games, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • SNES games like Super Mario World and Chrono Trigger boast stunning pixel art, making them easy to revisit.
  • Games like Lethal Enforcers and Yoshi's Safari impressed players with FMV and vibrant graphics on a 16-bit system.
  • Titles such as Donkey Kong Country and Super Mario RPG utilized clever design tricks to create visually impressive 3D effects.

Super Mario World, Chrono Trigger, and The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past are three of the best-looking games on the SNES. This makes them easy to go back to, thanks to the crisp pixel art. It’s why 16-bit games notably hold up the best compared to most other consoles, at least from Nintendo ones.

As great as these games are today, back in the 90s, other games stood out as technical marvels. They skirted the line between 2D and 3D, which was baffling to see on a 16-bit system like the SNES. While not all of these games hold up as well today, they were amazing when they were first released. They will be ranked based on how technically jaw-dropping they were for SNES games in the 90s.

8 Lethal Enforcers

How Did They Shrink Those People Into My Game?

  • Developer : Konami
  • Publisher : Konami
  • Released : January 1994 (SNES Version)
  • Platforms : Arcade, PS1, Sega CD, Sega Genesis, SNES

There were a few FMV games that made it onto the SNES that wowed players in the 90s. Lethal Enforcers started in arcades and digitized real actors to fill up the screen with hostages and terrorists. It was a simple trend for light gun games back then, along with other genres, including platformers and fighting games.

While the SNES version doesn’t look as good as the arcade or Sega CD versions, it is still one of the most impressive FMV games to ever grace the console.

7 Yoshi's Safari

Big Sprites, Bigger Gun

Yoshi's Safari
Rail Shooter
Action
Systems
Released
July 14, 1993
Developer(s)
Tose Co., Ltd.
Publisher(s)
Nintendo Co., Ltd.

Platform(s)
SNES
Powered by

Yoshi's Safari is another light gun game, and even though it didn’t use digitized live actors, the graphics were better. This is thanks in part to the animations of enemies moving more fluidly compared to the stiffness of Lethal Enforcers .

Sprites were big and colorful, especially during boss battles against the Koopalings. It’s a shame this game is hard to emulate on modern consoles now because it would still look good on the SNES retro selection for the Switch.

6 Super Mario World 2: Yoshi's Island

My Child Is Talented

Super Mario World 2: Yoshi's Island
8.5 /10
Released
October 4, 1995

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

ESRB
E For Everyone
Developer(s)
Nintendo EAD
Platform(s)
SNES, Nintendo Game Boy Advance
Powered by

Super Mario World 2: Yoshi's Island is another Yoshi vehicle that looked good back in the '90s and still holds up today. The colors are vibrant like Yoshi’s Safari , but what truly made the game remarkable was the overall art style, which looked crayon-like in design.

Somehow, the models also had a 3D effect, which is still hard to grasp. The chips within the SNES made it hard to port the game in perfect condition for years, and playing it on an actual SNES is still the best way to see the game.

5 ClayFighter 2: Judgment Clay

Forged In Fire

  • Developer : Interplay Productions
  • Publisher : Interplay Productions
  • Released : January 1, 1995
  • Platform : SNES

The first ClayFighter game looked on par with other digitized fighting games, including Mortal Kombat . Animations were stiff but still cool from a technical viewpoint. ClayFighter 2: Judgment Clay was a step above its predecessor as the digitized clay looked to retain more of their shapes as they fought on screen.

The N64 sequel blurred the lines even further, but ClayFighter 2: Judgment Clay tricked many young minds in the 90s that they were playing with clay molds, even if the game doesn’t appear as groundbreaking today.

4 Star Fox

Triangles In Space

Star Fox
Rail Shooter
Systems
Released
March 22, 1993
Developer(s)
Nintendo, Argonaut Software
Publisher(s)
Nintendo

Platform(s)
SNES
Powered by

Playing Star Fox now can look silly because it’s just a bunch of polygonal shapes, mostly triangles, firing at each other. There’s not much design to the ships of Fox McCloud and his crew or the enemy ships. It’s not impressive now, but for an early SNES game, players couldn’t believe their eyes.

Thankfully, the designs were clearer in the N64 sequel. The one thing that does hold up about Star Fox is the music in the first level, because it absolutely slaps.

3 Stunt Race FX

A Blocky Racer Rival To Super Mario Kart

Stunt Race FX
Released
June 4, 1994

Platform(s)
SNES, Nintendo Switch
Powered by

Super Mario Kart is the go-to racer on the SNES, but it’s not the visually pleasing one of the system. That would go to Stunt Race FX , a game most SNES fans have forgotten or maybe haven’t even heard of before.

Like Star Fox , the game used polygonal shapes to construct rough outlines of vehicles. The designs were much better in Stunt Race FX game thanks to a clever technical trick. Because the level of playing field was seen through a window, things ran better, which makes the game still look decent.

2 Donkey Kong Country

Rare Goes Bananas

Donkey Kong Country
9.0 /10
Released
November 24, 1994

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

ESRB
e
Developer(s)
Rare
Platform(s)
SNES, Nintendo Game Boy Color, Nintendo Game Boy Advance
Powered by

While fans wait for Donkey Kong Bananza to come out on the Switch 2, which looks absolutely stunning, let’s remember those warm, fuzzy feelings upon seeing Donkey Kong Country for the first time. “This is what video games can look like?!” That was probably screamed by many a kid in the '90s who got their hands on the game.

Donkey Kong, Diddy, Cranky, and all of the other Kongs and enemies were 3D models placed in a 2D world. That’s what it seemed like at least, but now it’s not as wow-inducing once the magic trick can be seen through. The trilogy is still fun to play on the SNES, though.

1 Super Mario RPG: Legend Of The Seven Stars

A Collaboration Worth Praising

Super Mario RPG: Legend of the Seven Stars
9.0 /10
Released
May 13, 1996

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

ESRB
E For Everyone
Developer(s)
Square
Platform(s)
SNES
Powered by

Squaresoft used similar tricks as Rare did with Donkey Kong Country when they designed Super Mario RPG: Legend of the Seven Stars . It was beyond impressive because Mario explored areas from a top-down perspective, thus giving a better illusion of 3D.

It’s not graphically powerful now, but the gameplay is still solid, which helped create the time-based combat system. Even modern games like Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 were inspired by Super Mario RPG: Legend of the Seven Stars , which is the game’s greatest legacy beyond art style by far.

item.title: Roblox Gets Banned Across Country
item.description:
Roblox players across the country of Qatar are discovering that the game has been completely banned. The surprising move has left players unable to access their favorite in- Roblox titles, and it's not clear if Roblox can do anything to resolve the situation.

While Roblox is an extraordinarily popular game platform, it has also faced a fair share of controversy over the years. One of the most alarming developments in recent history is a lawsuit against Roblox after a child was kidnapped. The child allegedly played Roblox and met someone in the game that they believed to be a teenager. However, the user was actually much older than that, and a predator. Upon meeting the user in real life, they were abducted. Even outside this issue, though, it seems the content within the game is apparently enough to give some governments pause.

Entire Country Bans Roblox

It's now coming to light that the country of Qatar has banned Roblox entirely. According to Qatar Tribune, the move came following a social media campaign asking for the game to be banned due to "potential risks to children and teenagers." On August 12, players started reporting that they were unable to access the game. While the app is reportedly still available for download, booting it up informs the user that they have no network access, while the web client says that the site simply can't be reached. Another publication, Al Jasra, noted that "incidents of virtual assaults" had transpired in the game, which may have also led to this move.

As of publication time, Roblox hasn't issued an official statement regarding the ban, so it's not clear how the company will react. However, this isn't the first time that Roblox has gone through something like this. In 2024, Roblox was blocked in the country of Turkey, which the government claimed was due to a lack of content regulation, as well as the monetization of the game. Roblox quickly responded to the ban by explaining that it would work with the Turkish government to restore access, so it's likely that it will do so again with the Qatar government in this latest ban.

Despite these controversies, overall, Roblox continues to thrive as a platform, reaching massive player counts. In addition to an estimated 380 million active monthly users, the game Grow a Garden on Roblox soared to a whopping 16 million concurrent players in June. Hopefully, gamers who have lost access to Roblox will be able to regain it soon.
